SEARCH
Package org.loudouncodes.jkarel

Class Arena

java.lang.Object
org.loudouncodes.jkarel.Arena
public class Arena extends Object
The place where the action happens. The Arena is a Singleton Class... that means there is only ever one of these in your program, you cannot say 'new Arena()', and you will always call methods on this class starting with the classname, like Arena.getPace();. The Arena is one of the primary classes you'll work with in this library. It opens Arena files, displays them on screen, brings 'life' to the robots as the move around the screen, and pretty much everything else. Wow! That sounds like it does a lot of stuff! But if you ever look at the code for an arena, you'll see that for the most part, it relies on other classes to do most of that work. This is a design pattern called a 'facade'. Its a way we can take a bunch of complexity and 'hide' it from the users of this framework.

      public static Pacing getPace()

      Returns:
      an enumeration defined in Pacing
      See Also:
      • Pacing

    • setPace

      public static void setPace(Pacing aPace)
      The Arena can be animated at different Paces; you can set the current pace setting with this method.
      Parameters:
      aPace - the pace enumeration we are setting this Arena to.
      See Also:
      • Pacing

    • getArenaFrame

      public static ArenaFrame getArenaFrame()
      Unless you are trying to do something advanced, you won't need to use this method. The Arena wraps a bunch of different things and displays them through this one interface. If for some reason you are learning about Java's Swing UI library, you can get the instance of JFrame that contains the Arena's UI.
      Returns:
      an instance of ArenaFrame animating the current UI.

    • setSize

      public static void setSize(int x, int y)
      Changes the size of the current world to the x and y values you pass to this method. Note that this doesn't change the size of the Arena's Window on your computer, this is the number of 'lanes' and 'avenues' your robots will be able to roam around on.
      Parameters:
      x - the number of avenues in this world.
      y - the number of lanes in this world.

    • addNorthWall

      Parameters:

      y - the y coordinate of the location where we are adding the wall,
